title: Ubuntu Application Switcher
description: Canonical Ltd. started developing Ubuntu for mobile devices. As part of this effort, I designed and prototyped an application switcher for Ubuntu Touch OS.

content.title: The UX Challenge
content.text:
Application switching is one of the most often performed tasks in both mobile and desktop operating systems. Hence it needs to be a fluid and frictionless interaction. For this project the main requirements were: 

‚Ä¢ Full convergence: the same switcher would need to work on phone, tablet and PC desktop. 
‚Ä¢ Needs to handle both windowed and non-windowed environments. 
‚Ä¢ Multiple workspace support needs to be taken into account. 
‚Ä¢ Needs to support all available input types: touch, pointer and keyboard. 
‚Ä¢ Single code base approach (stakeholder and engineering requirement). 
‚Ä¢ The existing design relying on stacked cards needs to be taken into consideration. 

 The main UX challenges:
 ‚Ä¢ How to create an adapting layout that transforms andcovers all use cases.
 ‚Ä¢ Creating consistent set of transitions and animations which would also be delightful to use and reinforce user‚Äôs metal model of the system.
 ‚Ä¢ Application window size can be arbitrary and vary between the windows simultaneously on the screen.
 ‚Ä¢ Horizontal space is limited but the design needs to scale to support 0-N application and 0-N workspaces.

content.title: The UX Approach
content.text:
Guiding design principles that helped in the design process:

 ‚Ä¢ Prefer subtle and unobtrusive animations to provide quick and consistent feeling across the use cases.
‚Ä¢ Utilise the screen real estate as well as possible and avoid overflow behind the screen edges.
‚Ä¢ Provide easily identifiable application info (card + icon + label).
‚Ä¢ Aim for full convergence: Same visual appearance, functionality and interactions across form factors, devices and input types.
‚Ä¢ Re-use existing Ubuntu design and visual patterns.

I wrote an interactive prototype to help in design.This turned out
to be invaluable approach that helped out to identify and solve many corner use cases. The prototype also worked as partial documentation for developers.

content.title: The final design
content.alt: An example image from the project.
content.caption: The same design and codebase works across phone, tablet and desktop form factors.
content.text:
The result layout is fully responsive that can adjust its element sizes, margins and visibility while maintaining balanced look and feel. Application widows are cropped in to a square shape with suitable cropping algorithm and application icon and label were added to maximise application identifiability. The final design supports following functionality: 

 ‚Ä¢ Application switching. 
‚Ä¢ Closing applications 
‚Ä¢ Moving applications between workspaces 
‚Ä¢ Closing, reordering and merging workspaces 
‚Ä¢ Focusing on to another workspace.

content.title: Impact
content.text: The converged switcher was part of Ubuntu 10.16 release as a default Unity 8 application switcher. The final implementation is essential part of a product that got awarded: üèÜ **Orange Award for Converged Computing** at Mobile World Congress 2017.

title: Accessible Version Control Change Indicators
description: Designing accessible change indicators for Visual Studio to enhance code management for developers with disabilities.

content.title: Project Overview
content.text: The code change indicators mark lines that have been modified, added, or deleted in the code file. The existing indicators in Visual Studio's version control system were not accessible for all users, and didn't provide the change type information being inconsistent with for example VS Code. I led the redesign work to ensure they were accessible and usable by all developers, regardless of their visual abilities.

content.title: UX Problem
content.caption: Caption text
content.text:
‚Ä¢ The indicators had 2 visual states **changed-not saved (yellow bar)**, and **changed-saved (green bar)** represented only by color. 
‚Ä¢ The change margin indicators don‚Äôt follow the Git status.
‚Ä¢ Works differently than for example Visual Code while the goal is to align with it.
‚Ä¢ Different kinds of changes are not distinguishable.
‚Ä¢ Not accessible for vision impaired users.
‚Ä¢ Color contrast ratio is not sufficient for passing WCAG standards.
‚Ä¢ Color blinds can‚Äôt distinguish unsaved changes from saved changes.

content.title: Design Process
content.text: First we conducted user research and usability testing with developers with visual impairments to understand their needs and challenges with the existing indicators. Collaborated with accessibility experts to ensure compliance with accessibility standards and guidelines. Explored various design options, including patterns, shapes, and textures, to create indicators that were easily distinguishable by all users. Developed prototypes and conducted iterative testing to refine the designs based on user feedback.

title: Visual Studio Copilot Integrations
description: Designing Copilot AI integrations across developer tools

content.title: Project Overview
content.text: Aligned GH Copilot integrations across toolsets throughout Visual Studio. I navigated competing constraints across different feature teams and aligned numerous stakeholders.

content.title: UX Problem
content.caption: UI full of inconsistencies confusing users, causing frustration, inefficiency, and discovery issues.
content.text: The user experience in different Visual Studio tools was inconsistent, didn't follow design guidelines, and lacked understanding of end-to-end scenarios. Teams worked in silos, leading to fragmented experiences that confused users and hindered productivity. There was a need to unify the design language, improve usability, and ensure accessibility across all Copilot integrations.

title: New Git Experience
description: Designing a new Git version control UX

content.title: UX Problem
content.alt: Version control interface with multiple issues highlighted.
content.caption: Multiple problems identified in the existing version control interface.
content.text: The version control interface in Visual Studio had several usability issues that hindered developers' productivity. Key problems included unclear status indicators, a cluttered layout, and inefficient workflows for staging and committing changes.

content.title: Research Findings
content.alt: Affinity diagram showing user research insights.
content.caption: Affinity diagram showing user research insights.
content.text: Together with program managers and researchers, we conducted user interviews and usability tests to gather insights into developers' pain points with the existing version control system. Key findings highlighted the need for clearer visual cues, simplified workflows, and better integration with other development tools.
